body:
Wasteland 3 is a post-apocalyptic game set in Colorado. The heroes are progressives -- ethnically diverse soldiers, originally led by a strong woman, Major Prasad. Prasad dies in the first chapter.

You must play as a duo of rangers. Choices include gay lovers and a father-daughter team. The poz is strong with this one.


The primary enemies are the rebellious factions of what seems to be a fundamentalist Christian sect. The bad guys of the first chapter talk with exaggerated accents. They sound like Hollywood voice actors who had been told to do Appalachian accents but had only prepared by watching Burt Reynolds in *Deliverance*. The rangers are on a mission to get help from "the Patriarch," who is the authorized leader of the rednecks. The sledgehammer angst and cheap drama of the first chapter lead me to suspect that the player will be encouraged to hate the Patriarch and all that he stands for, and to see cooperation with him as tragic. However, the game is not very interesting, so it is not likely that I will play most of it.


The people who made this game have some rabid fans who will praise it regardless of how it plays or what the story is like. The game makers had always been fans of cheap melodrama and sledgehammer angst, but to the best of my knowledge this is the first time they have nailed their rainbow-striped Pride flag to their mast.

A further note on the idiocy of the development team:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXeHwhLPKz8

One often-repeated piece of music is a version of an old Christian hymn. It is played by murderous Christians who all happen to be white. And yet ... the lyrics include the following:

>Have you learned to love your neighbours, of all colors, creeds and kind.

>Are you washed in the blood of the lamb?

>I've learned to love my people, of all colors, creeds and kinds.

>I'm all washed in the blood of the lamb

I take "my people" to mean "Christian people," but maybe it's even broader than that. It might have been intended to mean that Christians love everyone, even non-Christians.

So Christianity, which emphasized loyalty to spiritual brotherhood rather than racial brotherhood, actually put that emphasis into its hymns. Then some people who hate Christians stole the hymn for use in an anti-Christian game that implies all Christians are whites who hate non-whites. And yet they didn't bother to notice the lyrics which say that Christians love other Christians of all colors, creeds, and kinds.


Finally, as far as I can tell, the game is not buggy on PC, just boring. However, metacritic is full of complaints from console users that the game is buggy on consoles.

Update: 

Yeah, sorry to bother you all with this, I just needed to vent somewhere.

post.body:
Wasteland 3 is a post-apocalyptic game set in Colorado. The heroes are progressives -- ethnically diverse soldiers, originally led by a strong woman, Major Prasad. Prasad dies in the first chapter.

You must play as a duo of rangers. Choices include gay lovers and a father-daughter team. The poz is strong with this one.


The primary enemies are the rebellious factions of what seems to be a fundamentalist Christian sect. The bad guys of the first chapter talk with exaggerated accents. They sound like Hollywood voice actors who had been told to do Appalachian accents but had only prepared by watching Burt Reynolds in *Deliverance*. The rangers are on a mission to get help from "the Patriarch," who is the authorized leader of the rednecks. The sledgehammer angst and cheap drama of the first chapter lead me to suspect that the player will be encouraged to hate the Patriarch and all that he stands for, and to see cooperation with him as tragic. However, the game is not very interesting, so it is not likely that I will play most of it.


The people who made this game have some rabid fans who will praise it regardless of how it plays or what the story is like. The game makers had always been fans of cheap melodrama and sledgehammer angst, but to the best of my knowledge this is the first time they have nailed their rainbow-striped Pride flag to their mast.

A further note on the idiocy of the development team:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXeHwhLPKz8

One often-repeated piece of music is a version of an old Christian hymn. It is played by murderous Christians who all happen to be white. And yet ... the lyrics include the following:

>Have you learned to love your neighbours, of all colors, creeds and kind.

>Are you washed in the blood of the lamb?

>I've learned to love my people, of all colors, creeds and kinds.

>I'm all washed in the blood of the lamb

I take "my people" to mean "Christian people," but maybe it's even broader than that. It might have been intended to mean that Christians love everyone, even non-Christians.

So Christianity, which emphasized loyalty to spiritual brotherhood rather than racial brotherhood, actually put that emphasis into its hymns. Then some people who hate Christians stole the hymn for use in an anti-Christian game that implies all Christians are whites who hate non-whites. And yet they didn't bother to notice the lyrics which say that Christians love other Christians of all colors, creeds, and kinds.


Finally, as far as I can tell, the game is not buggy on PC, just boring. However, metacritic is full of complaints from console users that the game is buggy on consoles.

Update: 

Yeah, sorry to bother you all with this, I just needed to vent somewhere.

The "hundreds of thousands of variants" consist of minute copyist errors that are typically unique to a given manuscript, and never anything that affects doctrine. What's shocking is the impressive degree to which they are consistent despite their numbers. Also, please review your citation of Jeremiah 7 by cross-referencing it with Exodus 15, Hosea 6, 1 Samuel 15, and Psalms 40 and 51. This is a recurring theme, not a denial that the sacrifices were part of the Old Covenant, but that they are its visible sign and absolutely not its core.

The real giveaway of course is your kind's bizarrely dogmatic insistence that the Epistles are heavily edited, and when evidence is demanded, you say the church (which was under *intense persecution* at the time this would have to have occurred) somehow acquired and destroyed both the autographs and any accurate copies. Your entire evidence of "editing" consists wholly of a combination of wild misinterpretations to force "contradiction" (like claiming "there is neither male nor female" from Galatians is about egalitarianism, when the context makes clear that it's about salvation), deciding that something is written too differently so it can't possibly be from the same person (ignoring both different contexts of personal versus congregation oriented letters and the likelihood of a given letter being spoken by Paul and written by an assistant), or deciding that certain subjects like church governance wouldn't be a concern because... reasons.

body:
> The "hundreds of thousands of variants" consist of minute copyist errors that are typically unique to a given manuscript, and never anything that affects doctrine.

Incorrect. The most famous variants are the lack or inclusion of the *entire passages* Mark 16:9-20 and John 7:53-8:11. There are plenty of these kinds of variants and they occur multiple times in most chapters.

> This is a recurring theme, not a denial that the sacrifices were part of the Old Covenant, but that they are its visible sign and absolutely not its core.

I warned you already that Jeremiah 7 is nearly always mistranslated to make this appear to be the case. I'm guessing yours went something like:

> For when I brought your ancestors out of Egypt and spoke to them, I did not just give them commands about burnt offerings and sacrifices

But here is what it actually says:

> כי לא דברתי את אבותיכם ולא צויתים ביום הוציא הוציאי אותם מארץ מצרים על דברי עולה וזבח

> Because in the day I brought them out of Egypt, I did NOT speak to your ancestors nor command them about instructions for burnt offerings and sacrifices.

And then in the very next chapter (8:8), God explicitly calls out the scribes for having *tampered with the law*, thus confirming this is what's happening here:

> איכה תאמרו חכמים אנחנו ותורת יהוה אתנו אכן הנה לשקר עשה עט שקר ספרים

> How do you say, "We are wise, and Yahuwah's law is with us"? Behold, really the lying pen of the scribes writes to lie!

Now many attempt to get around this by saying "That was about commentaries!". But no, God *specifically* says his law, after denying that he gave parts of it which are indeed included in the copy we posess today. And this claim matches the evidence.

Wasteland 3 is a post-apocalyptic game set in Colorado. The heroes are progressives -- ethnically diverse soldiers, originally led by a strong woman, Major Prasad. Prasad dies in the first chapter.

You must play as a duo of rangers. Choices include gay lovers and a father-daughter team. The poz is strong with this one.


The primary enemies are the rebellious factions of what seems to be a fundamentalist Christian sect. The bad guys of the first chapter talk with exaggerated accents. They sound like Hollywood voice actors who had been told to do Appalachian accents but had only prepared by watching Burt Reynolds in *Deliverance*. The rangers are on a mission to get help from "the Patriarch," who is the authorized leader of the rednecks. The sledgehammer angst and cheap drama of the first chapter lead me to suspect that the player will be encouraged to hate the Patriarch and all that he stands for, and to see cooperation with him as tragic. However, the game is not very interesting, so it is not likely that I will play most of it.


The people who made this game have some rabid fans who will praise it regardless of how it plays or what the story is like. The game makers had always been fans of cheap melodrama and sledgehammer angst, but to the best of my knowledge this is the first time they have nailed their rainbow-striped Pride flag to their mast.

A further note on the idiocy of the development team:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXeHwhLPKz8

One often-repeated piece of music is a version of an old Christian hymn. It is played by murderous Christians who all happen to be white. And yet ... the lyrics include the following:

>Have you learned to love your neighbours, of all colors, creeds and kind.

>Are you washed in the blood of the lamb?

>I've learned to love my people, of all colors, creeds and kinds.

>I'm all washed in the blood of the lamb

I take "my people" to mean "Christian people," but maybe it's even broader than that. It might have been intended to mean that Christians love everyone, even non-Christians.

So Christianity, which emphasized loyalty to spiritual brotherhood rather than racial brotherhood, actually put that emphasis into its hymns. Then some people who hate Christians stole the hymn for use in an anti-Christian game that implies all Christians are whites who hate non-whites. And yet they didn't bother to notice the lyrics which say that Christians love other Christians of all colors, creeds, and kinds.


Finally, as far as I can tell, the game is not buggy on PC, just boring. However, metacritic is full of complaints from console users that the game is buggy on consoles.

Update: 

Yeah, sorry to bother you all with this, I just needed to vent somewhere.

Here is a (now deceased) Harvard Divinity school graduate explaining what I believe is the most obvious issue with modern Christian dogma:

https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=hwWi2H4bVX0

> The "hundreds of thousands of variants" consist of minute copyist errors that are typically unique to a given manuscript, and never anything that affects doctrine.

Incorrect. The most famous variants are the lack or inclusion of the *entire passages* Mark 16:9-20 and John 7:53-8:11. There are plenty of these kinds of variants and they occur multiple times in most chapters.

> This is a recurring theme, not a denial that the sacrifices were part of the Old Covenant, but that they are its visible sign and absolutely not its core.

I warned you already that Jeremiah 7 is nearly always mistranslated to make this appear to be the case. I'm guessing yours went something like:

> For when I brought your ancestors out of Egypt and spoke to them, I did not just give them commands about burnt offerings and sacrifices

But here is what it actually says:

> כי לא דברתי את אבותיכם ולא צויתים ביום הוציא הוציאי אותם מארץ מצרים על דברי עולה וזבח

> Because in the day I brought them out of Egypt, I did NOT speak to your ancestors nor command them about instructions for burnt offerings and sacrifices.

And then in the very next chapter (8:8), God explicitly calls out the scribes for having *tampered with the law*, thus confirming this is what's happening here:

> איכה תאמרו חכמים אנחנו ותורת יהוה אתנו אכן הנה לשקר עשה עט שקר ספרים

> How do you say, "We are wise, and Yahuwah's law is with us"? Behold, really the lying pen of the scribes writes to lie!

Now many attempt to get around this by saying "That was about commentaries!". But no, God *specifically* says his law, after denying that he gave parts of it which are indeed included in the copy we posess today. And this claim matches the evidence.

> Your entire evidence of "editing" consists wholly of a combination of wild misinterpretations to force "contradiction" (like claiming "there is neither male nor female" from Galatians is about egalitarianism, when the context makes clear that it's about salvation)

Since you bring up this particular contradiction so quickly when I had not mentioned it, I am suspicious that your motivations have something to do with this in particular. Is your entire reason for wanting "The Bible" to be inerrant so badly because you are afraid of "egalitarianism"?

> deciding that something is written too differently so it can't possibly be from the same person (ignoring both different contexts of personal versus congregation oriented letters and the likelihood of a given letter being spoken by Paul and written by an assistant)

1 Timothy contradicts Paul in essence and idea as well, not just style. And the style itself is very close to 2nd-century church fathers, not any kind of different. And the whole point of the letter is specifically attacking 2nd-century heresies which didn't exist in Paul's lifetime, especially Marcionism; and advocating centralized control of the church via orthodoxy.

> or deciding that certain subjects like church governance wouldn't be a concern because... reasons.

Early Christians got together in house churches and called no one on earth teacher or father or etc.

But to answer your question, unlike the Bible, we have an abundance of narrations and volumes of literature on the lives of people who met and lived with Muhammad (sallahu alayhi wasalam), and the people who met those people.

There are hadith that imply he could write:

https://sunnah.com/abudawud/20/72

But when you look at other narrations of the exact same event, it clarifies that indeed Muhammad (saw) had to ask where part of his epithet was on a letter:

https://www.islamforchristians.com/prophet-muhammad-illiterate/

>Sahih Muslim 1783c on the narration of Bara (I don't know why that website doesn't cite the hadith it mentions). 

https://sunnah.com/muslim/32

1783c

He had to ask to know where his name was on parchment. 

But I wish not for you to get hung up on this. Assume that the hadith are lying and that he could read. Assume that he had read the Bible thoroughly. Assume he had memorized the entire extant corpus of Christian literature in the 7th century. 

I personally present to you three assurances in your heart that he did not copy the Bible. If he did, he made two perfecting changes to the literature.

1) as far as I am aware, no Bible source refers to the King of Egypt as King, but rather uses Pharoah when speaking about the events in the life of Joseph. The Quran correctly uses King because it was before the title Pharoah was used (later like when Moses came to Pharaoh). At the time (7th century) Egyptian hieroglyphics were not known to anyone. 

2) Genesis correctly says that God created the Heavens and Earth in 6 "days" or "periods". The Quran clarifies that the Earth only took two of those periods. The Earth is 4.543 billion years old and the universe is 13.77 billion years old. Within 1-2% error, the ratio is exact as mentioned in the Quran. Genesis is not so clear on this. 

3) The Quran correctly posits that the Earth and the Heavens used to be a single mass, join into one, and then "unseamed" (same Arabic word is used when a button on clothes pops allowing joined entities to fly apart).

As far as I know, no Christian sources mention the prior unity and then unfurling of a joined mass of the Earth and Heavens. This was partially contained in Egyptian mythology (but probably wasn't available). If it was, Muhammad (saw) then must have miraculously picked the correct creation story if you believe him to be false.

Here is a source for number 2:

https://biblehub.com/text/genesis/41-45.htm

Egyptologist find that "Pharoah" wasn't used in the time of Joseph (thusly this is an error in the old testament introduced God-knows-when).

May God give you faith in Islam and Muhammad (saw). I know it is hard to accept. I genuinely believe it to be the truth and I hope that God strengthens your faith and soothes your heart.

It is a political title that describes mockingly that he was claiming to be King. Messih isn't a divine name. It simply means "anointed" or "chosen" in Hebrew. Rabbinical leaders (head priests), the King of Israel also had this title.

I know that and the Jews have been waiting for a leader with that title for a long time. In fact modern Jews who don't believe in Jesus are still waiting for one.

The Jesus mentions consistently through the entire Bible being "son of the father". And representing the will of the "father". This is definitely (my opinion) the Jesus that you're going to want to focus on, and probably the one that did miracles of God like healing the blind.

And also messiah. Like I said the Barabbas story is most likely a metaphor. The religious leaders chose the violent criminal over the messiah. And the former was set free by the latter's sacrifice.

The confusion is compounded by the fact that Jesus "son of the father" is indeed also the anointed and chosen. However, he was not the person claiming to be the king of the Jews who was being held prisoner.

How do you know it was actually written by Muhammad? Or that he was really illiterate? There are plenty of pseudographia in the Bible so I am aware of how easily this can be done.

The Quran offers a beautiful story explaining how the villagers were convinced that Mary was chaste despite carrying Jesus home. It is because Jesus spoke aloud to his mother's accusors as a newborn infant as a decisive miracle from God.

The virgin birth is only mentioned once in Matthew and once in Luke, and both are completely obvious later additions to the text. It's a trope and it never happened. Jesus thus meets the requirement that the messiah be of the seed of David.

Wasteland 3 is a post-apocalyptic game set in Colorado. The heroes are progressives -- ethnically diverse soldiers, originally led by a strong woman, Major Prasad. Prasad dies in the first chapter.

You must play as a duo of rangers. Choices include gay lovers and a father-daughter team. The poz is strong with this one.


The primary enemies are the rebellious factions of what seems to be a fundamentalist Christian sect. The bad guys of the first chapter talk with exaggerated accents. They sound like Hollywood voice actors who had been told to do Appalachian accents but had only prepared by watching Burt Reynolds in *Deliverance*. The rangers are on a mission to get help from "the Patriarch," who is the authorized leader of the rednecks. The sledgehammer angst and cheap drama of the first chapter lead me to suspect that the player will be encouraged to hate the Patriarch and all that he stands for, and to see cooperation with him as tragic. However, the game is not very interesting, so it is not likely that I will play most of it.


The people who made this game have some rabid fans who will praise it regardless of how it plays or what the story is like. The game makers had always been fans of cheap melodrama and sledgehammer angst, but to the best of my knowledge this is the first time they have nailed their rainbow-striped Pride flag to their mast.

A further note on the idiocy of the development team:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXeHwhLPKz8

One often-repeated piece of music is a version of an old Christian hymn. It is played by murderous Christians who all happen to be white. And yet ... the lyrics include the following:

>Have you learned to love your neighbours, of all colors, creeds and kind.

>Are you washed in the blood of the lamb?

>I've learned to love my people, of all colors, creeds and kinds.

>I'm all washed in the blood of the lamb

I take "my people" to mean "Christian people," but maybe it's even broader than that. It might have been intended to mean that Christians love everyone, even non-Christians.

So Christianity, which emphasized loyalty to spiritual brotherhood rather than racial brotherhood, actually put that emphasis into its hymns. Then some people who hate Christians stole the hymn for use in an anti-Christian game that implies all Christians are whites who hate non-whites. And yet they didn't bother to notice the lyrics which say that Christians love other Christians of all colors, creeds, and kinds.


Finally, as far as I can tell, the game is not buggy on PC, just boring. However, metacritic is full of complaints from console users that the game is buggy on consoles.

Update: 

Yeah, sorry to bother you all with this, I just needed to vent somewhere.

>How do you know it was actually written by Muhammad? Or that he was really illiterate? There are plenty of pseudographia in the Bible so I am aware of how easily this can be done.

140,000 people knew him and heard his final sermon in person. He said in front of them "today your religion is perfected". I don't know how better he could fit the description of the paraclete.

But to answer your question, unlike the Bible, we have an abundance of narrations and volumes of literature on the lives of people who met and lived with Muhammad (sallahu alayhi wasalam), and the people who met those people.

There are hadith that imply he could write:

https://sunnah.com/abudawud/20/72

But when you look at other narrations of the exact same event, it clarifies that indeed Muhammad (saw) had to ask where part of his epithet was on a letter:

https://www.islamforchristians.com/prophet-muhammad-illiterate/

>Sahih Muslim 1783c on the narration of Bara (I don't know why that website doesn't cite the hadith it mentions). 

https://sunnah.com/muslim/32

1783c

He had to ask to know where his name was on parchment. 

But I wish not for you to get hung up on this. Assume that the hadith are lying and that he could read. Assume that he had read the Bible thoroughly. Assume he had memorized the entire extant corpus of Christian literature in the 7th century. 

I personally present to you three assurances in your heart that he did not copy the Bible. If he did, he made two perfecting changes to the literature.

1) as far as I am aware, no Bible source refers to the King of Egypt as King, but rather uses Pharoah when speaking about the events in the life of Joseph. The Quran correctly uses King because it was before the title Pharoah was used (later like when Moses came to Pharaoh). At the time (7th century) Egyptian hieroglyphics were not known to anyone. 

2) Genesis correctly says that God created the Heavens and Earth in 6 "days" or "periods". The Quran clarifies that the Earth only took two of those periods. The Earth is 4.543 billion years old and the universe is 13.77 billion years old. Within 1-2% error, the ratio is exact as mentioned in the Quran. Genesis is not so clear on this. 

3) The Quran correctly posits that the Earth and the Heavens used to be a single mass, join into one, and then "unseamed" (same Arabic word is used when a button on clothes pops allowing joined entities to fly apart).

As far as I know, no Christian sources mention the prior unity and then unfurling of a joined mass of the Earth and Heavens. This was partially contained in Egyptian mythology (but probably wasn't available). If it was, Muhammad (saw) then must have miraculously picked the correct creation story if you believe him to be false.

Here is a source for number 2:

https://biblehub.com/text/genesis/41-45.htm

Egyptologist find that "Pharoah" wasn't used in the time of Joseph (thusly this is an error in the old testament introduced God-knows-when).

May God give you faith in Islam and Muhammad (saw). I know it is hard to accept. I genuinely believe it to be the truth and I hope that God strengthens your faith and soothes your heart.

>Why does the system of personal revelation and faith that every pre-Mosaic believer and arguably all true believers used suddenly stop working at the time of Muhammad?

As God says in the Bhagavad Gita before the Torah... 

https://www.holy-bhagavad-gita.org/chapter/4/verse/8

>To protect the righteous, to annihilate the wicked, and to reestablish the principles of dharma I appear on this earth, age after age.

This wording should be taken extremely lightly as the Bhagavad Gita has probably been tampered more than the old testament. 

There isn't a legitimate religion except that it was instilled into a man by God. 

https://bhagavad-gita.org/Gita/verse-16-06.html

I don't know why. I cannot fathom the intention of the one who cannot be fathomed. Honestly (I mean it), I don't know why He, the exalted made us to worship Him, and to test us. The purpose of my life Insha'Allah is to do right by the covenant that He has offered me, and to meet Him. For this, I yearn. Muhammad (saw) said that you will be with God and there will be no interpreter between you and God. I want the pleasure and approval and happiness of God so that I might come to know in that life the why of this existence. He, the unfathomable and every living could have done whatever He wanted. As Arjun said to Krishna, "I cannot fathom your intention" (11.31). The Hindus today don't know who either of those two entities were/are. It was a messenger expressing himself to the one true God. And I must agree with his remark.

>And if God needs a perfect book for the world, then why does he wait thousands of years to have it made?

We believe the Quran to be uncreated, direct communication from God to you. But to answer the sentiment of your question, I honestly don't know. It is what I believe, but I don't know why God has made this world like it is. I am well convinced of the books but I don't comprehend His intention. Perhaps to test us? If he spoke directly to every descendant of Adam as He did to the early humans, we would have no ability to disbelieve. 

>genesis firmament

I don't know Hebrew to comment on the connotations and essence of the word or the scholarship around this question. I will simply say that I find the Quranic description miraculous:

https://quran.com/21/30

Unlike the purported genesis exerpt, there is a clear notion of explosion/tearing/expanding in time. A firmament seems like a static wall, a division. I understand you feel that it is copied. The Quran verse is just too clean for me to have that concern.

You do realize the implication that the Quran is alluding to the big bang? I don't feel that the firmament verses so clearly reference this. Perhaps you don't agree that the universe is expanding outwards from its "center"?

Wasteland 3 is a post-apocalyptic game set in Colorado. The heroes are progressives -- ethnically diverse soldiers, originally led by a strong woman, Major Prasad. Prasad dies in the first chapter.

You must play as a duo of rangers. Choices include gay lovers and a father-daughter team. The poz is strong with this one.


The primary enemies are the rebellious factions of what seems to be a fundamentalist Christian sect. The bad guys of the first chapter talk with exaggerated accents. They sound like Hollywood voice actors who had been told to do Appalachian accents but had only prepared by watching Burt Reynolds in *Deliverance*. The rangers are on a mission to get help from "the Patriarch," who is the authorized leader of the rednecks. The sledgehammer angst and cheap drama of the first chapter lead me to suspect that the player will be encouraged to hate the Patriarch and all that he stands for, and to see cooperation with him as tragic. However, the game is not very interesting, so it is not likely that I will play most of it.


The people who made this game have some rabid fans who will praise it regardless of how it plays or what the story is like. The game makers had always been fans of cheap melodrama and sledgehammer angst, but to the best of my knowledge this is the first time they have nailed their rainbow-striped Pride flag to their mast.

A further note on the idiocy of the development team:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXeHwhLPKz8

One often-repeated piece of music is a version of an old Christian hymn. It is played by murderous Christians who all happen to be white. And yet ... the lyrics include the following:

>Have you learned to love your neighbours, of all colors, creeds and kind.

>Are you washed in the blood of the lamb?

>I've learned to love my people, of all colors, creeds and kinds.

>I'm all washed in the blood of the lamb

I take "my people" to mean "Christian people," but maybe it's even broader than that. It might have been intended to mean that Christians love everyone, even non-Christians.

So Christianity, which emphasized loyalty to spiritual brotherhood rather than racial brotherhood, actually put that emphasis into its hymns. Then some people who hate Christians stole the hymn for use in an anti-Christian game that implies all Christians are whites who hate non-whites. And yet they didn't bother to notice the lyrics which say that Christians love other Christians of all colors, creeds, and kinds.


Finally, as far as I can tell, the game is not buggy on PC, just boring. However, metacritic is full of complaints from console users that the game is buggy on consoles.

Update: 

Yeah, sorry to bother you all with this, I just needed to vent somewhere.

post.body:
Wasteland 3 is a post-apocalyptic game set in Colorado. The heroes are progressives -- ethnically diverse soldiers, originally led by a strong woman, Major Prasad. Prasad dies in the first chapter.

You must play as a duo of rangers. Choices include gay lovers and a father-daughter team. The poz is strong with this one.


The primary enemies are the rebellious factions of what seems to be a fundamentalist Christian sect. The bad guys of the first chapter talk with exaggerated accents. They sound like Hollywood voice actors who had been told to do Appalachian accents but had only prepared by watching Burt Reynolds in *Deliverance*. The rangers are on a mission to get help from "the Patriarch," who is the authorized leader of the rednecks. The sledgehammer angst and cheap drama of the first chapter lead me to suspect that the player will be encouraged to hate the Patriarch and all that he stands for, and to see cooperation with him as tragic. However, the game is not very interesting, so it is not likely that I will play most of it.


The people who made this game have some rabid fans who will praise it regardless of how it plays or what the story is like. The game makers had always been fans of cheap melodrama and sledgehammer angst, but to the best of my knowledge this is the first time they have nailed their rainbow-striped Pride flag to their mast.

A further note on the idiocy of the development team:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXeHwhLPKz8

One often-repeated piece of music is a version of an old Christian hymn. It is played by murderous Christians who all happen to be white. And yet ... the lyrics include the following:

>Have you learned to love your neighbours, of all colors, creeds and kind.

>Are you washed in the blood of the lamb?

>I've learned to love my people, of all colors, creeds and kinds.

>I'm all washed in the blood of the lamb

I take "my people" to mean "Christian people," but maybe it's even broader than that. It might have been intended to mean that Christians love everyone, even non-Christians.

So Christianity, which emphasized loyalty to spiritual brotherhood rather than racial brotherhood, actually put that emphasis into its hymns. Then some people who hate Christians stole the hymn for use in an anti-Christian game that implies all Christians are whites who hate non-whites. And yet they didn't bother to notice the lyrics which say that Christians love other Christians of all colors, creeds, and kinds.


Finally, as far as I can tell, the game is not buggy on PC, just boring. However, metacritic is full of complaints from console users that the game is buggy on consoles.

Update: 

Yeah, sorry to bother you all with this, I just needed to vent somewhere.

parent.body:
>Why does the system of personal revelation and faith that every pre-Mosaic believer and arguably all true believers used suddenly stop working at the time of Muhammad?

As God says in the Bhagavad Gita before the Torah... 

https://www.holy-bhagavad-gita.org/chapter/4/verse/8

>To protect the righteous, to annihilate the wicked, and to reestablish the principles of dharma I appear on this earth, age after age.

This wording should be taken extremely lightly as the Bhagavad Gita has probably been tampered more than the old testament. 

There isn't a legitimate religion except that it was instilled into a man by God. 

https://bhagavad-gita.org/Gita/verse-16-06.html

I don't know why. I cannot fathom the intention of the one who cannot be fathomed. Honestly (I mean it), I don't know why He, the exalted made us to worship Him, and to test us. The purpose of my life Insha'Allah is to do right by the covenant that He has offered me, and to meet Him. For this, I yearn. Muhammad (saw) said that you will be with God and there will be no interpreter between you and God. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXeHwhLPKz8

>Have you learned to love your neighbours, of all colors, creeds and kind.

>Are you washed in the blood of the lamb?

>I've learned to love my people, of all colors, creeds and kinds.
